Award.AwardTitle: Bilateral NSF/BIO-BBSRC: Synthetic DNA Nanopores for Selective Transmembrane Transport

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transport of small molecules across biological membranes is essential for cells; it enables removal of waste from cells, replenishing of nutrients, and secretion of messenger molecules. Energy-independent transport is facilitated by protein pores and channels that often are selective for a particular cargo, and have defined width and surface charge. All known transmembrane pores are made of protein. In synthetic biology, there is a need to design new kinds of pores, suitable for moving one kind of cargo. In this collaborative project, investigators from the US (Arizona State University) and the UK (University College London) combine expertise from membrane nanopore research and DNA nanotechnology to generate novel versions of membrane pores that are similar in properties to protein pores but are made of DNA.

The project exploits the recent breakthrough on simple membrane-spanning DNA nanopores and build structurally and functionally advanced pores of tunable size, charge properties, and activity. DNA nanopores will be designed and constructed to enable the programmable tuning of pore diameter, charge selectivity, and stimulus-controlled activities. The DNA nanopores of predictable structures will be tailored for applications including the development of membrane compartments for light-triggered release of proteins useful in cell biological research, and enzymatic membrane nanoreactors for the localized activation of anti-cancer prodrugs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nature is an extremely smart and self-sustainable entity. Biological systems such as human body are highly sophisticated engineering designs that runs in efficiency almost close to 100%. Nature has already figured ways to sustain multiple species without harming their surroundings. If we can mimic nature it will enable creation of technologies that will be far more advanced and sophisticated than the systems we currently work with. As an example ? if we can replace our currently used memory storage devices such as CD drives, flash drives by nature?s energy storage material which is DNA ? we will be able to store all data generated in the world by humans in 2021 in approximately half gram of material (source: IDC reports of world data sphere). This shows just one example of the power of the field biomimetics or biomimicry which is the emulation of the models, systems, and elements of nature for solving complex human problems.

Our current project is a biomimetics project that emulates a class of protein in our body that is crucial for almost all our senses such as visualizing, hearing, feeling taste, heat etc. The ability to mimic these ion channels will lead to various technological breakthroughs such as ? developing cheaper and faster diagnostic methods for virus related diseases (by improving the speed of genome sequencing by nanopore sequencing), improved drug delivery methods for side-effect free chemotherapy, discovering new drugs for complex neurodegenerative diseases (by enabling study of the protein folding processes involved in these diseases) etc. 

A unique specialty of biological systems, especially proteins, is their high structural precision that makes them extremely efficient. A major challenge in mimicking the biological systems is mimicking this structural precision. For example ? man made systems called nanopores have been invented that share similarity with biological ion channels. However, they can not function as precisely as ion channels because the current fabrication technologies do not have nanoscale precision required to mimic the ion channels. DNA nanotechnology is the only technology that can offer this precision. 

In our current project, we have used the principles of DNA nanotechnology to develop, for the first time, an analogue of natural ion channels that not only mimic and expand the functions of biological ion channels but also overcome limitations of native, engineered and de-novo protein pores. They provide unrivalled control over the pore diameter, charge selectivity in transport and trigger-controlled activities, thus leading to designed functions for light-gated opening of pore for protein cargo, size and charge selective transport of small molecules excluding proteins.

One key reason for neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer?s disease is protein misfolding. Technologies that enable study of protein folding-unfolding has potential to enable discovery of cures for these diseases. One way of studying these protein folding events is nanopore biosensing. Nanopore biosensing is basically if a blind person sits beside an open door through which air is flowing. Now although the person is blind (like we are blind when it comes to nanoscale systems such as proteins which are too small to see by bare eyes), when someone passes through that door there will be a fluctuation in the air flow. Now if the person is sensitive enough ? they can sense the movement of a person through the door without visually seeing them. By sensing difference of air flow it will be possible to differentiate an elephant from a dog (see picture below).

The enclosed imageis to  compare"door-air flow" analogy to nanopore biosensing. Adapted from Varongchayakul et al, Nat Biotech, 2012.

Nanopore biosensing basically uses ionic flow in place of air and a nanopore in place of door to the above analogy. Now for studying protein folding-unfolding by these methods, it will be beneficial if the proteins can be fit inside the nanopore (the door). Current nanopores are not big enough. In our project we have created a nanopore that is big enough to house proteins. This has potential to solve a major bottleneck in the field and lead to discovery of new cures for neurodegenerative and several other diseases caused by protein misfolding.
